Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Act committed abroad equivalent to serious crime in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in determining inadmissibility under s. 36(1)(c) of IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 36(1)(c)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's husband acquitted in the Philippines due to victim's pardon but found to have committed the act; act equivalent to a Canadian offense punishable by at least 10 years imprisonment
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Committed an act abroad that is equivalent to a serious crime in Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in assessing inadmissibility despite acquittal
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Act must be equivalent to an offense punishable by at least 10 years imprisonment in Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Equivalency of foreign act to Canadian criminal offense
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Husband found to have committed the act despite acquittal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Findings from Philippine proceedings, evidence of act and pardon
Crimes.Application_Basis: Committing an act outside Canada equivalent to a serious indictable offense in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Nature of the act, foreign pardon, lack of recognition of foreign pardon under Canadian law
Crimes.Governing_Rule: IRPA s. 36(1)(c): inadmissibility for acts abroad equivalent to serious crimes in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found â€“ sufficient evidence established commission of act
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential risk to Canadian society due to seriousness of equivalent offense
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant's husband deemed inadmissible due to committing an act abroad equivalent to a serious crime in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Foreign pardon not recognized as negating inadmissibility when incompatible with Canadian values
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Acquittal based on pardon, not innocence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Extraterritorial application of Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Commission of act established on balance of probabilities
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Foreign pardon does not preclude finding of inadmissibility under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Weight given to foreign legal outcomes under Canadian immigration assessment

Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual in the Philippines who pardoned the perpetrator
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Seriousness of sexual assault, potential for reoffending
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Victim's pardon leading to acquittal in local jurisdiction
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Equivalent to an offense punishable by at least 10 years imprisonment in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to establish commission of the act on balance of probabilities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, foreign court records, pardon documentation
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible evidence that act occurred despite acquittal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Act was committed; acquittal due to pardon, not factual innocence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to nature of sexual offense
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential harm to individuals if admitted to Canada
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, non-consensual sexual act against specific individual
Crimes.Geographic_Context: Incident occurred abroad, assessed under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Canadian immigration authorities applying domestic standards to foreign conduct
Crimes.Applicable_Statute: Criminal Code of Canada (for equivalency assessment)
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities (civil standard in immigration context)
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A (no Canadian conviction; immigration consequence only)
Crimes.Procedural_Issues: Scope of judicial review, deference to administrative decision-makers
Crimes.Legal_Procedure: Federal Court judicial review under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Authority: Immigration officer acting under delegated authority
